Row.Text: [LIST] [LI]Before you embark on your journey to create an empire that stands the test of time, take a look at some of the fundamental concepts of the latest installment in this series. [LI]Once you begin the game, you will see [b]tutorials [/b]that will teach you how to play, and expert [b]Advisors [/b]who will guide your decisions. The [b]Civilopedia [/b]will also be available at any time, where you can refer to any of the game's concepts or learn the history behind them.[/b][/LIST]

[LIST][LI]A game of Civilization VII consists of multiple [b]Ages[/b]. Every turn brings you a step closer to the next Age; some important events are a leap forward. [LI]Each Age presents its own [b]unique gameplay, new challenges, and an opportunity to change your strategy[/b]. Your [b]Leader [/b]remains the same, but at the end of every Age you will choose a new [b]Civilization[/b], with a different set of Abilities and Units at your disposal. The Legacy you create with each Civilization will carry into subsequent Ages.[/LIST]

[LIST][LI][b]Legacy Paths [/b]are the primary means by which you can create continuity from one Age to the next. [b]Every Age presents four such paths: Economic, Cultural, Scientific, and Militaristic. [/b]Whether you focus solely on one path or diversify your efforts, the progress you make will [b]grant you unique and powerful abilities in the next Age[/b]. [LI]In the final Age, once you [b]complete a Legacy Path[/b], you will have the opportunity to [b]perform one more decisive feat to seal your Victory[/b].[/LIST]

[LIST][LI]Your people will live in [b]Settlements[/b], where you can direct their training, construction, and growth. [LI]There are two kinds of Settlement: [b]Cities and Towns[/b]. [b]Cities can use Production [/b]to train Units and construct Buildings. [b]Towns cannot use Production[/b], but they create additional Food and Gold for your Civilization, as well as provide other bonuses based on the Focus you give them. [LI]Your first Settlement will be a [b]City[/b]. Afterwards, you will need Settlers to create new Towns, which you can then convert into Cities.[/LIST]
Discover the world and command your forces

[LIST][LI]Moving [b]Units [/b]around the map is a critical part of how you interact with the world; they allow you to explore new places, establish friendly relations with [b]Villages [/b]and other [b]Players[/b], or engage in hostilities with them. [LI]While Military Units can fight on their own, placing [b]Commanders [/b]nearby can greatly improve their effectiveness. [b]Commanders can efficiently move groups of Units and earn experience to unlock powerful combat bonuses.[/b] [LI]Even if your goal is peace, a standing army can deter potential threats.[/LIST]

[LIST][LI]You are not alone in this world, and your actions will affect your relationships with both other [b]Players [/b]and smaller, [b]Independent Powers[/b]. Whether you have settled too close to another's borders or have a shared enemy, your relationships with others determine how they behave towards you. [LI]But as in real life, all relationships are bound to change. With enough [b]Influence[/b], you can befriend a hostile Village, go to war with a former ally, or reconcile with your enemy.[/LIST]

[LIST][LI]Every game of Civilization VII is its own journey, and as you will see from the following [b]tutorials [/b]and [b]Advisor [/b]messages, there are countless ways to build an empire that stands the test of time. To make the most of your journey, try to remain open to these ideas and be willing to adapt when necessary. [LI]Good luck! Remember, you can always open the [b]Civilopedia [/b]for more information.[/LIST]
Return the Joy-Con 2 to the Mouse position to learn more about [b]Mouse Controls[/b], or close to continue playing.
Return the Joy-Con 2 to the Mouse position to learn more about [b]Mouse Controls[/b], or close to continue playing.
Return the Joy-Con 2 to the Mouse position to learn more about [b]Mouse Controls[/b], or close to continue playing.
[b]Press [/b][action:{1_Icon}] [b]to cancel[/b]. [n]If you'd like to exit [b]Mouse Controls[/b], [b]turn the Joy-Con 2 [/b]upright at any time.
Here your journey begins. Raise an empire from humble beginnings to greatness, and write your own version of history.

Greetings, [b]{1_LeaderName}[/b]![n]With a new vision come the {2_CivAdj} people, ready to put down roots in these fertile lands.[n]Your [icon:UNIT_FOUNDER] [b]{3_Founder} [/b]has the ability to establish your first [icon:YIELD_CITIES] [b]City[/b]. {4_Prompts}

Your first settlement is sure to thrive near sources of water and abundant resources. This location is well-suited to your needs![n]Order your [icon:UNIT_FOUNDER] [b]{1_Founder} [/b]to establish your [b]Capital City[/b], {2_Prompts} the [icon:UNIT_FOUND_CITY_ICON] [b]{LOC_UNITOPERATION_FOUND_CITY_NAME} [/b]action button located in the Unit panel below.

Behold [b]{1_CityName}[/b], the cultural center of the [b]{2_CivAdj} [/b]people![n]This [b]City [/b]and all your future [b]Settlements [/b]provide your Civilization with specific yields:[n][n][icon:YIELD_FOOD] [b]Food [/b]to feed your people and grow your populace.[n][n][icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] [b]Production [/b]to construct special Buildings and train Units.[n][n][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] [b]Science [/b]to propel your people into the future and progress to greater things.
Use [b]the scroll wheel[/b] to zoom in and out.
Use [action:{1_Icon}] to zoom in and [action:{2_Icon}] to zoom out.

A [b]Settlement [/b]generates an amount of [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] [b]Production [/b]every game turn. This [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] [b]Production [/b]can be used for many things, like constructing important new [b]Buildings [/b]or training powerful [b]Military Units[/b]. A [b]City [/b]should always be producing something. [n][n] {1_Prompts}
Press [action:{1_Icon}] while hovering over [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_CITY_PRODUCTION] [b]Choose Production [/b]to begin.

The [b]City's [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production [/b]panel contains the projects it can currently begin.[n]Currently you have the option of producing two different types of Units:[n][n]{1_DescA}[n][n]{2_DescB}[n][n][b] {3_Prompts} begin their training[/b].
Press [action:{1_Icon}] on an option to select it and
The [b]{1_Name} {2_Icon} [/b]Unit can navigate difficult terrain to [b]explore [/b]the world, revealing it quickly.
The [b]{1_Name} {2_Icon} [/b]is a military Unit that can [b]attack [/b]hostile enemies or defend your City from an invasion.
Excellent! Training will begin at once.[n][n]In Civilization, players take turns to make their decisions before advancing. [n][n]Since there is nothing else to address at this time, {1_Prompts}
[b]press [/b][action:{1_Icon}] on [icon:NEXT_TURN] [b]Next Turn[/b] to end your turn.

While the lands surrounding your City are visible, the rest of the world remains [b]unrevealed[/b]. This is represented by the patterned tiles near the edges of your world view.[n][n]Exploring the lands beyond is key to your Civilization's survival and prosperity.
When a Unit moves toward the extent of its vision, the lands beyond reveal themselves.[n][n]{1_AddDesc}

Your recently trained {1_Icon} [b]{2_ReconUnit} [/b]stands ready to explore the world. A light blue outline represents the extents it can move in a single turn.[n]{3_Prompts}tile to move your [b]{2_ReconUnit} [/b]toward an unrevealed part of the map.

Your recently trained {1_Icon} [b]{2_MilitaryUnit} [/b]can venture forth into those lands, [b]or [/b]it can remain nearby to defend your City from outside threats.[n][n]A light blue outline represents the extents the [b]{2_MilitaryUnit} [/b]can move in a single turn. Try moving it now by{3_Prompts}tile.

A Unit's [icon:UNIT_MOVEMENT_ICON] [b]Movement [/b]speed is the maximum number of tiles it can travel in a turn. Most Units have a Movement speed of 2, but some can move farther. [n][n]Keep in mind that certain map features like [b]Rough Terrain or Water [/b]can consume a Unit's remaining moves, ending its Movement for the turn.

New Technologies emerge when people put their minds to solving great problems.[n][n]Whichever Tech you pursue next will determine the tools you have at your disposal to build your Civilization. What path will you choose first?[n] {1_Prompts}
Press [action:{1_Icon}] to select [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_TECH] [b]Choose Technology[/b] option below.
Press [action:{1_Icon}] on the [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_TECH] [b]Choose Technology[/b] option below.

What Technologies you [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_TECH] [b]Research [/b]will determine the tools you have at our disposal, like [b]Buildings [/b]and military [b]Units[/b], as well as the ability to construct incredible [b]Wonders of the World[/b].[n][n]{1_Prompts} a Technology to see a detailed description of what it unlocks.[n][n]Once you've decided what to begin, {2_Prompts}
click on the Technology to begin researching.
confirm your Tech choice by pressing [action:{1_Icon}].
press [action:{1_Icon}] on the Technology to begin researching.
tap on the Technology to begin researching.

[icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_TECH] [b]Research [/b]takes time to complete. That amount of time is equal to the [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] [b]Science [/b]required divided by the Science your Civilization generates per turn.[n][n][b]{1_Tech} [/b]has a Science cost of {2_Cost}. Since we currently generate {3_Amount} [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] [b]Science [/b]per turn, we can expect research to [b]complete in {4_Turns} turns[/b].[n][n]Increasing your [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] [b]Science [/b]per turn allows you to [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_TECH] [b]Research new Techs faster[/b]. Getting ahead of the competition is a wise strategy for success.

The Technology Tree is a comprehensive view of all of the Technologies available through the entire Age.[n]The paths connecting each Technology indicate the prerequisites required in order to research future Techs. Use the tree as a guide to find the quickest path to a specific Tech or Tech Mastery.
Since the training of your first Unit has completed, you are free to choose what to [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_CITY_PRODUCTION] [b]Produce [/b]next.

You now have the ability to construct a [b]Building [/b]in your City. [b]Buildings [/b]provide additional yields and effects to the City where they reside.[n]You can choose to build a [b][icon:BUILDING_GRANARY] {LOC_BUILDING_GRANARY_NAME}[/b] or a [b][icon:BUILDING_FISHING_QUAY] {LOC_BUILDING_FISHING_QUAY_NAME}[/b], if you settled adjacent to Coast; or you could also train a second [b]Unit[/b]. Any choice is good.
Reconnaissance is essential for keeping a close eye on our surroundings, and we already have a sufficient military presence.
Our military strength is currently lacking, and we have our reconnaissance covered.

When constructing a new [b]Building[/b], you must choose a placement location.[n][n][b]Buildings [/b]can be placed in an [b]Urban District [/b]with an empty slot, represented by the [b]dark green [/b]color, or you may [b]annex a new Urban District tile[/b], represented in [b]light green [/b]color by placing it there.[n][n][b]Yellow [/b]tiles contain existing [b]Rural population and their Improvements[/b], placing a [b]Building [/b]on these tiles is possible, but will [b]replace the Improvement[/b].[n][n][b]Red [/b]tiles, such as [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources [/b]or [b]Mountains[/b], can not be built upon.
Thanks to the amount of [icon:YIELD_FOOD] [b]Food [/b]your City has generated, it has [b]grown in population[/b]![n]{1_Prompts}
Press [action:{1_Icon}] on the [icon:NOTIFICATION_NEW_POPULATION] [b]Grow City [/b] to continue.

When a City grows, it can [b]expand into an adjacent tile, gaining the yields it offers[/b]. When your Settlement's people move to this tile they'll create an [b]Improvement[/b], a [b]Rural structure [/b]for them to work and live in.[n][n]Tiles with high yields and tiles containing resources are an obvious choice, but specific yield type may better suit your strategy.[n][n]Choose where you would like to expand first.

Your Civilization accumulates wealth in the form of [icon:YIELD_GOLD] [b]Gold [/b]which is generated every turn from various sources including Buildings, Resources, and land Improvements as well as Civic Policies and trades.[n][b]Gold [/b]is a very powerful resource which can be used to purchase things instantly that would normally require time and Production to obtain. However, keep in mind that most Buildings and Units have a [b]Gold [/b]maintenance cost which is subtracted from your Treasury each turn. Maintaining a positive [b]Gold [/b]income is important!

Recent expansion has allowed you to improve a [icon:{1_ResourceType}] [b]{2_ResourceName} [/b]Resource. [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources [/b]grant bonuses or abilities to the City that holds the [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resource [/b]or to your entire Civilization.[n][n][icon:{1_ResourceType}] [b]{2_ResourceName} [/b]has this effect:[n]{3_ResourceDesc}. {4_ResourceTarget}[n][n]Remember: [b]Buildings [/b]cannot be placed atop [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources[/b], so placing Rural population on them is always a great idea.
This is a [b]City Resource[/b], so it can only be assigned to [b]Cities[/b].
This is an [b]Empire Resource[/b], so it effects your entire Civilization.
This is an [b]Bonus Resource[/b], so it can be assigned to any Settlement.

A [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Route [/b]has been created with one of your Settlements. [n]Trade Routes will award the Player who initiated it a copy of each [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resource [/b]in the other Player's Settlement. In return, the other Player receives [icon:YIELD_GOLD] [b]Gold [/b]every turn.
Don't forget to explore your surroundings! Keep moving your Units to reveal {1_GoalNum} tiles in the lands beyond.
You have met your first exploration goal. Go forth to seek new lands beyond the horizon.

You can now build [b]{1_WonderName}[/b], a [b]World Wonder[/b]![n][b]Wonders [/b]are special Buildings that grant unique abilities and strong yields, but occupy an [b]entire tile [/b]in a Settlement. Some Wonders require a specific Terrain or natural features to be built, and they occupy an [b]entire tile [/b]in a Settlement. [n][b]Only one of each Wonder can exist in the world[/b], so the first Civilization to complete construction keeps the Wonder. Consider building Wonders that match your playstyle.

Congratulations! You have completed construction of your first Wonder of the World, [b]{1_WonderName}[/b]. [n][n]This is a significant accomplishment for the {2_CivAdj} people, and your first step along the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_CULTURE_NAME} Legacy Path.
You now have the opportunity to train a [b]{1_SettlerName} [/b]Unit. These Units can found new [b]Towns, [/b]an essential part of your Civilization's growth.

New notions of society have led to the development of [b]{1_CivicName}[/b]. This first Civic allows you to form a [b]Government [/b]and enact [b]Social Policies[/b], powerful bonuses unlocked as you progress through the [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]Civic tree[/b].
Each [b]Civic [/b]unlocks new [b]Social Policies[/b], as well as unique effects that benefit your Civilization.[n][n]Once you've decided what to study first, [b]{1_Prompts} the Civic to begin[/b].
You will need to establish a [b]Government [/b]before you can enact [b]Social Policies[/b].[n][n]Each form of government has its own unique effects. [b]Choose your Government now.[/b]

Under your new Government, you may enact a [b]Social Policy[/b]. Complete [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]Civics [/b]throughout the Age to earn more Policies to enact.[n][n][b]Choose your first Social Policy[/b]:
You can adapt your Civilization's strategies by swapping Social Policies. If you want to swap a Policy, you will need to research a Civic.

You have earned your first [icon:ATTRIBUTE] [b]Leader Attribute [/b]point![n][n]These let you customize your Leader to fit your play-style. To choose your first Attribute, {1_Prompts} the [icon:ATTRIBUTE_ARROW] [b]Attribute [/b]icon on your Leader's portrait.
press [action:{1_Icon}] to access the [b]Radial Menu [/b]and select

[icon:ATTRIBUTE] [b]Attributes [/b]you choose will [b]apply [/b]for the remainder of the [b]current Age [/b]as well as [b]all future Ages [/b]that this Leader participates in.[n][n]Some points are for specific attributes, but [icon:ATTRIBUTE_WILDCARD] [b]Wildcard [/b]points can be spent anywhere.

Your new [b]{1_SettlerName} [/b]is ready to expand the reach of the {2_CivAdj} Civilization with a new Settlement.[n][n]As with the first, look for fertile land with good yields and close access to water.

Your people have made a new home, providing you with your first [b]Town[/b]. Like a City, [icon:YIELD_FOOD] Food from this Settlement allows you to expand into nearby tiles. However, Buildings and Units in Towns can only be [b]purchased [/b]with [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold.[n][n]You can also spend Gold to turn a Town into a full-fledged City, though the Gold cost is greater the more Cities you have in your Civilization and decreases as the [b]Town [/b]grows.
{1_CityName}'s defenses have fallen, bringing the Settlement under your control and expanding your Civilization.

Now that {1_cityName} is under {2_civAdj} control, you must choose what to do with this Settlement:[n][b]Keeping this Settlement [/b]will bring {1_cityName} into your Civilization as a [b]Town[/b]. Its citizens will be furious, but placing a [b]Commander [/b]in the Town could bring order.[n]Alternatively, you may [b]Raze {1_cityName}[/b], removing it from the map. Razing a Settlement takes [b]multiple turns and cannot be canceled[/b]. You will also incur various Diplomatic penalties.[n][n]Consider your options carefully, as this will affect your reputation and the reputation of the {2_civAdj} people.

Bringing {1_cityName} into {2_civAdj} society has created grief and turmoil for the people of this Settlement.[n]For the next [b]10 turns, [/b]{1_cityName} will be in a state of [b]Unrest, [/b]resulting in a [b]-15 [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] [b]Happiness [/b]penalty[/b]. Unhappiness can cause [b]Yield penalties in this Settlement[/b], so you may want to [b]station a Commander [/b]here to reduce the effects of Unrest while it lasts.

With each new Settlement, the reach of your Civilization grows. [b]Founding more Towns and Cities [/b]will expand your reach and start your people down the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} Legacy Path, but [b]capturing the Settlements [/b]of other Civilizations will put your people on a faster but more vicious path to the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} Legacy.

You have encountered a stranger from the [b]Village[/b] of [b]{1_IndependentName}, [/b]and they appear to be [b]{2_Relationship}[/b].[n]The Village could potentially be a strong ally with the right amount of persuasion, but it could also prove a threat to your Civilization. Finding the location of {1_IndependentName} would be wise.[n]Independent Villages [/b]can have different attitudes towards others: [b]Friendly[/b], [b]Neutral, [/b]or [b]Hostile[/b].[n]Once you have found a Village, you can use [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]to begin [b]Diplomatic Actions[/b], such as [b]{LOC_DIPLOMACY_ACTION_GIVE_INFLUENCE_TOKEN_START_ACTION_NAME}[/b], to improve your Relationship with it.

You have discovered a [b]Village [/b]called [b]{1_IndependentName}, [/b]which appears to be [b]{2_Relationship}.[n]The Village could potentially be a strong ally with the right amount of persuasion, but it could also prove a threat to your Civilization.[n]Independent Villages [/b]can have different attitudes towards others: [b]Friendly[/b], [b]Neutral, [/b]or [b]Hostile[/b].[n]Once you have found a Village, you can use [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]to begin [b]Diplomatic Actions[/b], such as [b]{LOC_DIPLOMACY_ACTION_GIVE_INFLUENCE_TOKEN_START_ACTION_NAME}[/b], to improve your Relationship with it.

You have just met [b]{1_LeaderName}[/b]! Good diplomatic relationships with other Leaders can yield [b]powerful benefits [/b]for your Civilization, but they are also your main [b]rivals [/b]in achieving victory. Before starting Diplomatic Relations with other Leaders and their people, we should greet them. You can give a [b]Friendly, Neutral[/b], or [b]Hostile [/b]greeting. The choice is yours.

Here you can interact with another Leader and see information about them, such as their [b]Civilization[/b], [b]Agenda[/b], your [b]Relationship [/b]with them, [b]Diplomatic Actions [/b]you can start with them, and other information. To open this screen for a Leader, simply select their Leader portrait.

A variety of sources can affect your [b]Relationship [/b]with another Leader, including Diplomatic Actions, [b]World Events [/b]such as settling too close to their capital, and their unique Agenda. A Helpful Relationship can lead to an [b]Alliance[/b], and a Hostile Relationship is more likely to lead to [b]War[/b]. Keep in mind that the other Leader can also affect your Relationship in the same ways, so it is prudent to keep an eye on it from time to time.

Your Relationship with [b]{1_leaderName} [/b]has deteriorated, and you have become [b]Hostile [/b]towards each other.[n]At any point, you can declare Formal War against {1_leaderName} via their Leader Banner screen or by moving Units into their territory. You can also choose to repair your Relationship by starting a [b]Reconciliation Action [/b]with them.

It looks like your Relationship with {1_leaderName} has changed due to their [b]Agenda[/b]. Remember, you may not need to directly communicate with another Leader for your Relationship to strengthen or deteriorate.[n]You can check their profile to view more information on the status of your Relationship and their Agenda.

You can start a variety of Diplomatic Actions with another Leader by spending [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence[/b]. These Actions can have a variety of effects and generally last for a fixed period of time. They include:[n][n][b]Endeavors[/b], which are helpful to both of you and increase your Relationship[n][b]Sanctions[/b], which are harmful to the other Leader and decrease your Relationship[n][b]Espionage Actions[/b], which are generally hidden from the other Leader.

All Diplomatic Actions, except Espionage and Sanctions, will require the other Leader to give a response, which may have an [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]cost. [n]They include:[n][n][b]Support[/b], which is exclusive to Endeavors and can grant more powerful effects at the cost of Influence[n][b]Accept[/b], which is the default free option[n][b]Reject[/b], which cancels the action at the cost of some Influence.

Map [b]Resources [/b]grant unique effects when acquired in one of your Settlements. By nature, that effect is applied to the Settlement that owns it. However, most Resources can be allocated to another Settlement and apply their effects there instead.

It is time to choose a [icon:NOTIFICATION_CHOOSE_BELIEF] [b]Pantheon [/b]to represent the ethos of your Civilization.[N]Once you or another Leader has chosen one of the available Pantheons, it becomes unavailable for any other player. Most Pantheons require an [icon:BUILDING_ALTAR] [b]Altar Building [/B]to function.

This might be a good time to start training a [b]{1_Commander} [/b]Unit to lead your growing military. You can use a {1_Commander} to move multiple Units quickly around the map and provide them with strong combat bonuses and abilities.

[b]Commander [/b]Units earn [b]experience [/b]when one of their nearby Units engages in combat. After gaining enough experience, you can choose powerful [b]Promotions [/b]that can enhance the combat effectiveness of nearby Units, or unlock new abilities.
Your {1_CommanderName} has earned enough experience from combat to earn their first [b]Promotion[/b]! To grant this Commander a Promotion, {2_Prompts} the [b]Promote [/b]action button.

Your Commander has access to many different Promotions organized into several discipline trees. Each promotion unlocks a new ability or skill your [b]Commander [/b]can use on the battlefield.[n][n]You can choose to diversify the skills of your Commander Units, or you can specialize by focusing on a specific discipline tree.

Our new Support Unit, the [b]{1_UnitName}[/b], should be moved to a foreign Settlement to establish a [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Route[/b]. You will need to train a new [b]{1_UnitName} [/b]for each additional Trade Route you want to set up. A [b]Trade Route [/b]grants you access to the other Settlements' [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources[/b], which can then be allocated to your own Settlements.

The people of {1_cityName} are distressed by ongoing war. You have committed less Diplomatic Support than your opponent, causing [b]War Weariness[/b].[n][n]Each point of War Weariness reduces the Combat Strength of all your Units against that opponent by 1 and reduces [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] [b]Happiness [/b]in all of your Settlements. The Happiness penalty is higher in Settlements you capture in the current Age and higher still if those Settlements were founded by a Civilization you are currently at war with.[n][n]You can spend [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]to add Support to your wars and uplift the people of the {2_civAdj} Civilization, or, if you add enough Support, even impose War Weariness on your enemies instead.

Conquering another Civilization involves capturing all of its Settlements.[n][n]To do so, your military Units must attack and [b]take control of the Settlement's center District, as well as any Districts that have walled defenses[/b]. A walled Settlement is more challenging to capture, and its defenders more difficult to defeat.[n][n]Be sure to bring a large military force when embarking on such a campaign, but don't forget to also keep a strong military presence at home to defend your own Settlements.

You have reached the limit on how many Settlements your Civilization can easily maintain. If you acquire additional Settlements, you will take a -5 [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] [b]Happiness [/b]penalty to all of your Settlements for each one over the limit.[n][n]Look for Settlement limit increases in the [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]Civic[/b], [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] [b]Tech[/b], and [icon:ATTRIBUTE] [b]Attribute [/b]trees to further grow your Civilization.

You have achieved your first [b]Milestone [/b]on a Legacy Path. The first time a Milestone is completed by any Civilization the [b]Age Progress [/b]meter increases. When the Age Progress meter is full, this Age will End, and players will enter an [b]Age Transition [/b].[n][n]Additionally, every Milestone grants a [b]Legacy Point [/b]to any Civilization that completes it. There are four types of Legacy Points, one for each Legacy Path, which can be used during Age Transition to choose which Legacies you want to carry forward into the next Age.

A City cannot be captured by an enemy as long as its walled fortifications still stand. Constructing them in your City Center is best, and building them in your other Districts increases your security, as an invader will have to destroy all of your [b] Fortified Districts [/b]in order to capture the City.

Newly finished fortifications have brought much needed protection to the {1_City_Town} of {2_Name}. [b]{3_FortificationName} [/b]increase this district's health by [b]{4_Health} [/b]and grants [b]+{5_Strength} [/b]to its defensive strength.[n][n]Units that occupy these defenses can only be damaged by siege attacks.

Ranged Units like the [b]{1_UnitName} [/b]have the ability to attack from more than one tile away from their target. Additionally, the defender does not have the opportunity to retaliate.[n][n]It is a wise strategy to order your Ranged Units to attack first, damaging and weakening the enemy, before sending your Melee Units in to attack the target.

Siege Units like the [b]{1_UnitName} [/b]are ideal for attacking enemy Settlements. Not only do they ignore any defensive bonus granted by wall fortifications, they also deal damage to Units that occupy those defenses.[n][n]It is a wise strategy to bring at least one Siege Unit along with your army when planning an attack.

Your newly constructed [b]{1_UnitName} [/b]is now ready for combat. Although they are ideal for attacking Settlements, [b]Siege Units [/b]are vulnerable to counterattack, so it is essential to keep them protected with stronger Melee Units. Siege Units also generally move more slowly than their Infantry counterparts, so packing them in with a Commander ensures they arrive at the battlefield in good time.

Exploration has revealed a {1_DiscoveryName}, one of many [b]Discoveries [/b]that can be found in the world. Closer inspection grants a hidden benefit or opportunity; try moving one of your Units there to see what it provides.

Naval Units like the [b]{1_UnitName} [/b]can move quickly and unimpeded through inland and coastal waterways. In addition to engaging enemies on the water, they have the ability to conduct ranged attacks against Units on land.[n][n]Keep in mind that in the Antiquity Age, the open oceans remain impassable, so your movement is limited to Navigable Rivers and the shallow waters surrounding land.

You have encountered an enemy Army on the battlefield and have entered their [b]Zone of Control[/b]. In order to advance to attack them you must first deploy your troops. If you chose not to attack, you can use any remaining movement to retreat outside of their Zone of Control.

You have formed an [b]Alliance [/b]with another Leader. Spend [b]Diplomatic Currency [/b]to unlock [b]Open Borders [/b]with your ally. If either party declares war on the other, [b]Grievances [/b]equal to the support of the Alliance will be generated.

You have unlocked a [b]Diplomatic Sanction[/b].[n][n]Sanctions are actions you take [b]against [/b]another Civilization, like imposing a limit on one of their yields or hindering their research.[n][n]Like all Diplomatic Actions, Sanctions require [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence[/b]. The more [b]Influence [/b]spent on the Sanction, the greater effect it will have, but the target of the Sanction has the opportunity to counter it with their own [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence[/b].[n][n]Like other Diplomatic Actions, Sanctions can be accessed by clicking on your ribbon or the ribbon of a specific Leader you want to interact with. This will bring up the appropriate Diplomacy page, where you can select the "Start Sanction" button to see the list of available actions.

You have unlocked an [b]Espionage [/b]Action.[n][n]Espionage Actions are taken [b]secretly [/b]against another Civilization. If all goes well, your target will know that the action has happened but won't know who was responsible.[n][n]Espionage Actions are risky: they always have a chance of being [b]Revealed, [/b]and sometimes have a chance of failing altogether. If your Espionage Action is Revealed, your target will know that you were behind the action and you will receive a penalty to your [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence[/b].[n][n]To maintain secrecy, Espionage actions take time and care to complete. Unlike other Diplomatic Actions, Espionage Actions have an ongoing [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]cost that you must maintain, or else they will fail.[n][n]If you suspect that someone might be targeting you with an Espionage Action, you can use the [b]Counterspy [/b]action against them to thwart their plans.

[icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] [b]Happiness [/b]measures your people's satisfaction with you.[n]Settlements send you excess Happiness. After enough excess Happiness has been accrued, you will earn a Celebration! Settlements with negative Happiness will receive yield penalties.[n]To earn Happiness settle near fresh water, slot [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources [/b]that grant Happiness, and construct Happiness Buildings and Wonders. Poor Settlement management and ongoing Wars can reduce Happiness in Settlements.[n][n]Don't fret, your Advisors are here to monitor your [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] [b]Happiness [/b]and alert you of any issues.

Congratulations! Because you have maintained your people's [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness well, they have decided to have a [b]Celebration [/b]in your honor![n][b]Celebrations [/b]are periods of time when your people are more productive, and it's up to you where they direct this new energy. Keep an eye on the duration, as [b]Celebrations [/b]do not last forever.

The Town of {1_townName} has truly begun to establish itself as a home for the {2_civAdj} people. Towns are critical for your economy, as their [b][icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production is converted to [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold[/b].[n]You can spend [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold to upgrade a Town to a City, though there are trade-offs. The upgrade cost decreases the more populous the Town becomes, but as a City it won't bring in as much [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold as before.[n]Consider keeping {1_townName} a Town for now so that it can adopt a [b]Focus [/b]later.

The Town of {1_townName} has grown enough to [b]Focus[/b]![n]Focused Towns will generate extra yield and other benefits, but be careful: [b]Towns can only Focus once[/b], and are locked into that decision for the rest of the Age.[n][n]While a Town has its chosen Focus active, it will stop growing and instead send all of its food to Cities it is [b]Connected [/b]to. A City and Town are Connected if there is a Road directly between them or if they are both Coastal and on the same Continent. Once unlocked, you can use Merchants to build roads between Settlements to ensure that they are Connected.[n][n]A Town can continue growing even after you've chosen a Focus by switching between your chosen Focus and the Growing Town option.

You now have the ability to place Specialists in Cities.[n]Like [b]Rural population[/b], which can be placed on unimproved tiles, [b]Specialists [/b]can be placed on existing Urban tiles to create dense Urban districts.[n]Be careful: while Specialists [b]increase [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science, [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture and other yields[/b], they also [b]increase the [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness and [icon:YIELD_FOOD] Food needed by the Settlement[/b].[n]It may be best to wait to place Specialists until Rural tiles become less desirable.
Your Civilization can now produce Great Person Units. Each Great Person has a unique effect, which can be activated in specific locations.

You can now build the [b]{1_BuildingName}, [/b] a [b]Unique Building[/b]! This building is unique to the {2_CivAdjective} civilization, and has special bonuses.[n][n]You can unlock [b]another unique building by continuing to study the {3_CivName} Civic Tree[/b]; put both in the same district to create a [b]Unique Quarter [/b]and unlock even more special bonuses![n][n]The {2_CivAdjective} Unique Quarter, the {4_QuarterName}, grants the following effect on completion: [b]{5_QuarterEffect}[/b]

{1_SettlementName} can now build another [b]{2_CivAdjective} Unique Building[/b], the [b]{3_CityNeedsBuilding}[/b]. Building the {3_CityNeedsBuilding} and {4_CityHasBuilding} in the same district will create the {2_CivAdjective} Unique Quarter: [b]the {5_QuarterName}[/b]! [n][n]The {5_QuarterName} will grant the following effect: [b]{6_QuarterDescription}[/b]

Age Progress increases a small amount every turn but will also increase by larger amounts when a [b]Milestone [/b]is completed, a Future Tech or Civic is researched, or a Leader is [b]Defeated[/b]. Once the meter is at 95% (on Standard Speed), Age Progress cannot be added through normal means and a [b]10 turn countdown [/b]will begin. Each turn will add 1 Age Progress. Once the meter is completely filled, the [b]Antiquity Age [/b]will give way to the [b]Exploration Age, [/b]and all Leaders will enter an [b]Age Transition [/b]where they will decide what Civilization will carry their [b]Legacy [/b]forward. Complete Milestones on Legacy Paths to unlock more powerful Legacy options.

{1_leaderName} has been [b]Defeated[/b]. Age progress increases when a Leader is [b]Defeated[/b]. Once the meter is completely filled, the [b]Antiquity Age [/b]will give way to the [b]Exploration Age[/b].[n][n]Defeated Leaders are permanently removed from the Campaign.

The Age Progress meter is completely filled. At the end of this turn, the [b]Antiquity Age [/b]will give way to the [b]Exploration Age, [/b]and you will enter an [b]Age Transition[/b], during which you will choose how the {1_civAdj} Civilization will evolve and what the Legacy of your accomplishments in this Age will be. [n][n]History is built in layers, and progress often comes with setbacks. All the Settlements you control at the Age Transition and your [b]{2_civName} Traditions [/b]will form the foundation you will continue to build upon, but only your Capital will retain its status as a [b]City[/b]. Ageless Buildings, Improvements and Wonders will carry over with full yields and adjacencies. Other Buildings will lose their adjacencies and effects and become Overbuildable.

Gameplay specific to the [b]Antiquity Age, [/b]such as Pantheons; your current Government; City-States; Trade Routes; and Diplomatic Relationships will be replaced by new forms unique to the [b]Exploration Age[/b]. [n][n]Your [b]Commanders [/b]will persist into the next Age, and some Units will remain and upgrade to [b]Exploration Age [/b] counterparts. [n][n]The first stage of your journey is ending, but a new world of possibilities is beginning. Prepare to discover new technologies, cultures, peoples, and continents as you enter the [b]Exploration Age![/b]

You've met a stranger from a small independent [b]Encampment [/b]called [b]{1_IndependentName}[/b]![n][n]Units from Encampments will raid and pillage nearby settlements, as they are always Hostile and cannot become Friendly.[n][n]Once you have found their Encampment, you can use the [b]Incite Raid [/b]action to direct their attacks elsewhere. You can also temporarily [b]Disperse [/b]the Encampment, but it will reappear somewhere nearby after a few turns.

You've encountered an [b]Encampment [/b]called [b]{1_IndependentName}[/b]![n][n]Units from Encampments will raid and pillage nearby settlements, as they are always Hostile and cannot become Friendly.[n][n]You can use the [b]Incite Raid [/b]action to direct their attacks elsewhere. You can also temporarily [b]Disperse [/b]the Encampment, but it will reappear somewhere nearby after a few turns.

A [b]Crisis [/b]is growing in your Civilization, unlocking a [b]Crisis Policy[/b]. The negative effects of such Policies reflect your Civilization's difficulty in responding to the Crisis. As the Crisis deepens, you will unlock new Crisis Policies and Crisis Policy slots.[n][n][b]Crisis Policy slots can only hold Crisis Policies. Choose your first Crisis Policy now.[/b]

Civilizations are remembered for their accomplishments and the paths they take through history. Some spread their accomplishments across a wide range, while others are devoted to a single cause.[n]Your Advisors are at your service to guide you on the path of your choice. Like any great leader, you may change your mind at any time.[n]Now, choose where to focus the efforts of the {1_civAdj} people.
(Legacy Paths are currently disabled. If you enable them, your Advisors will be at your service to guide you on the path of your choice.)
Trade is the lifeblood of our people, and gold the foundation of our dreams.
Security is our only path - strike swiftly and build our empire to see a new dawn.
Only great monuments of beauty and inspiration can lift our people out of darkness.
Knowledge remakes the world; we should be the ones doing the making.
{1_PathDescription}[n]Your [b]{2_Advisor} [/b]is here to guide you in this path if you wish.[n]Note that you can change paths at any time.
Focus on building your Trade empire to achieve greatness throughout the known world!
Spread your empire far and wide by establishing and capturing more settlements than any other civilization!
Become the envy of all other cultures by building great wonders of the world!
Research and acquire technological knowledge to become the most advanced civilization in the world!
You can check your current tracked goals and objectives at a glance in your Civilization Journal.
Checking your overall Legacy progress as well as other Legacy paths can be viewed in the Age Progress panel.[n]{1_Prompts} the [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]Age Progress [/b]icon.
Press [action:{1_Icon}] to access the [b]Radial Menu [/b]and select

The world contains innumerable mysteries waiting to be discovered, and I, your humble Science Advisor, intend to show you the way. [n]Let us begin by devising a way to record our very thoughts. Such records would not only allow us to hold a mirror up to nature, but to harness its power and reshape the world.

Objective: [b]Research [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] {LOC_TECH_WRITING_NAME}[/b], the first step towards establishing a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n][n]Remember: [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]Legacies [/b]improve your performance in later Ages, but [b]you can choose to pursue one, multiple, or none at all[/b].

With knowledge of {LOC_TECH_WRITING_NAME}, our dreams are as real as lines in the sand but also as fragile. Whatever we choose to record, we must ensure it lives on for all time. [n]Let us set our discoveries down in a Codex and store it in a {LOC_BUILDING_LIBRARY_NAME}.

Some [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] [b]Technologies [/b]and [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]Civics [/b]have a second more advanced tier that can be researched once the base version is complete. These advanced [b]Techs [/b]and [b]Civics [/b]will award you with a [b]Codex [/b]of knowledge that can be placed inside of a [icon:BUILDING_LIBRARY] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_LIBRARY_NAME}[/b]. [n]Next Objective: [icon:BUILDING_LIBRARY] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_LIBRARY_NAME} [/b]and earn a [b]Codex [/b]by completing [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] [b]Research [/b]on [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] [b]{LOC_TECH_WRITING_NAME} II[/b].

The Codex is complete a testament to our people's scientific rigor. [n]But I believe that the mysteries of the world have only grown, and we shall need to develop institutions capable of unraveling them, and more Codices to contain them.

You've achieved a great Milestone in {1_CivAdj} [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science! Codices are essential for progressing toward a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Victory in this Age, but you will need to gather more and provide ample [b]space for them to be housed[/b]. [n]Next Objective: [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] [b]{LOC_TECH_MATHEMATICS_NAME} [/b]and build an [icon:BUILDING_ACADEMY] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_ACADEMY_NAME} [/b]in one of your Settlements.

This new {LOC_BUILDING_ACADEMY_NAME} shall stand as a temple to knowledge, I know it. Already, the greatest {1_civAdj} minds are gathering in its halls, ready to build a legacy of discovery one Codex at a time.

You will need to direct the {1_CivAdj} people to collect more [b]Codices [/b]by [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] [b]Researching [/b]Masteries, [b]becoming Suzerain [/b]of Scientific City-States, and interacting with [b]Discoveries[/b]. [n]Next Objective: [b]display 3 Codices[/b], achieving the first Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path.
Three Codices now grace our halls of learning, containing the collected knowledge of the {1_civAdj} people. What secrets yet elude us?

You have achieved the first [b]Milestone [/b]in the [b]{LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path[/b]! Continue to collect [b]Codices [/b]to earn further rewards. [n]Next Objective: [b]display 6 Codices[/b], achieving the second Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path.
We now possess six Codices. {1_civAdj} wisdom grows by the day, and the darkness of ignorance recedes ever further.

You have achieved the second great [b]Milestone [/b]in the [b]{LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path[/b]! Continue to collect [b]Codices [/b]to earn the last group of rewards. [n]Next Objective: [b]display 10 Codices[/b], achieving the third and [b]final [/b]Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path.

Our collection of Codices is the envy of the world, a veritable garden of knowledge that will bear fruit for ages to come.The mysteries of the universe are innumerable, but we should regard our work with pride.

Congratulations! You've [b]displayed ten Codices [/b]and successfully completed the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Legacy Path of the Antiquity Age. [n]You can visit the [b]Legacy Path Screen [/b]to see more Legacy Paths you can follow, or you can forge your own path.

I am your Culture Advisor, an expert on arts, philosophy, and all other things worth thinking about. We have the opportunity to build a unique feat of engineering and artistry a [b]Wonder[/b], making us the object of envy of all our neighbors. Who has need to conquer cities, when you can conquer hearts?

Objective: [b]Build a Wonder[/b], the first step towards establishing a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_CULTURE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Cultural Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n]You will be able to unlock Wonders via the [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]Civic [/b]and [icon:NOTIFICATION_TECH_DISCOVERED] [b]Tech [/b]trees. [n][n]Remember: [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]Legacies [/b]improve your performance in later Ages, but [b]you can choose to pursue one, multiple, or none at all[/b].
We have completed our first Wonder! This will surely assist us in our efforts to create a [b]lasting Cultural impact[/b]. Of course, our people will want more Wonders now.

The {1_CivAdj} people will need to complete more Wonders to complete this Legacy Path within the Antiquity Age. [n]Next Objective: [b]Construct a second Wonder[/b], achieving the first Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_CULTURE_NAME} Legacy Path.
Another monument to beauty rises, and again the {1_CivAdj} people have upheld their reputation as builders of Wonders. But reputations require reinforcement. They'll expect another.

By building a second Wonder, you've achieved a great Milestone for {1_CivAdj} [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture! With the first Milestone complete, you've already unlocked some rewards for the next Age. [n]Next Objective: [b]Construct {2_WonderNum} Wonders[/b], achieving the second Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_CULTURE_NAME} Legacy Path.

With a fourth Wonder completed, the fame of the {1_CivAdj} burns brightly. But like any fire, fame requires constant refueling. We don't want to be the people that began building Wonders and then stopped, do we?

By building four Wonders, you've achieved a second Milestone for {1_CivAdj} [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture! Completing the next quest will [b]complete [/b]the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_CULTURE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture Legacy Path, earning you special rewards as your Civilization grows beyond the Antiquity Age. [n]Next Objective: [b]Construct {2_WonderNum} Wonders[/b].

We can rest the pick and trowel for now - with the completion of a seventh Wonder, the {1_CivAdj} Cultural Legacy has been secured. Long after the {1_CivAdj} people have faded from the world's stage, their name will still be remembered as those who placed beauty above all else.

Congratulations! You've built seven Wonders and successfully completed the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_CULTURE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture Legacy Path of the Antiquity Age. [n]You can visit the [b]Legacy Path Screen [/b]to see more Legacy Paths you can follow, or you can forge your own path.
Time is precious, so let me be brief I am your Economic Advisor, and I intend to make you rich. [n]There is a bounty in the world's Resources. Let us make certain that we are the ones to reap it.

Objective: Study [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]{LOC_CIVIC_CODE_OF_LAWS_NAME} [/b]Civic as soon as possible to unlock the [b]{1_UnitName} [/b]Unit, which has the ability to establish [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Routes[/b]. [n][icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Routes [/b]will grant you [icon:YIELD_GOLD] [b]Gold[/b], [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources[/b], and progress for the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_GOLD] Economic Legacy Path. [n][n]Remember: [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]Legacies [/b]improve your performance in later Ages, but [b]you can choose to pursue one, multiple, or none at all[/b].

We now have a [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]{LOC_CIVIC_CODE_OF_LAWS_NAME}[/b], and more importantly, a [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] {1_UnitName}. [n]If you send the {1_UnitName} to a Settlement beyond our borders, it will acquire for us riches beyond our dreaming. But make no mistake this is only the start.

Objective: Create a [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Route[/b], the first point you will score towards a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_GOLD] Economic Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n]To do this, you must take your new {1_UnitName} to a friendly foreign Civilization and use the [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Create Trade Route [/b]Action. You'll need to pick a [b]nearby Settlement [/b]as your traders can only travel so far right now.
Move: {1_UnitName} to foreign land[n]Initiate: Trade Route
At last, a [b]Trade Route[/b]. Our pockets are heavier already, but there must be more we can gain from this arrangement.

Your new [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Route [/b]grants you access to all of the resources that Settlement has improved, which can be distributed to your Settlements to gain their bonuses. Initially, we can only have one [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Route [/b]to each foreign power. If you initiate the Diplomatic Action [b]Improve Trade Relations[/b], you can increase that to two Routes. [n]Next Objective: [b]Improve Trade Relations [/b]with another power.
Improve Trade Relations with a Civilization
Good a strong relationship is the foundation of trade. As long as we are not at War with another Civilization, then what's theirs will be ours. Let us see what else our associates can offer us.

Every [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resource [/b]you receive, via [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade [/b]or expansion, progresses you along the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} [/b]Legacy Path, earning you special rewards as your Civilization grows beyond the Antiquity Age.[n]Next Objective: Slot 7 [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] Resources, achieving the first Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} Legacy Path.
With so many [b]Resources[/b] at our disposal, the wealth of the world is ours to enjoy. I see no reason to stop.
Next Objective: Slot 14 [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] Resources, achieving the second Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} Legacy Path.
Our accumulation of Resources impresses even myself. Before long, our legacy as the world's marketplace will be undeniable.
Next Objective: Slot 20 [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] Resources, achieving the third and final Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} Legacy Path.
After so much [b]Trade [/b], we have finally reaped a bounty of [b]Resources[/b] as befits a great empire. Well and wisely done.

Congratulations! You've acquired 20 [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resources [/b]and finished the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_ECONOMIC_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_GOLD] Economic Legacy Path of the Antiquity Age.[n]You can visit the [b]Legacy Path Screen [/b]to see more Legacy Paths you can follow, or you can forge your own path.

I am your military advisor. A veteran of many wars, I live to serve you and preserve our empire through strength. [n]Our warriors are bold and fierce, but victory on the battlefield requires discipline above all. We must train our soldiers quickly to keep enemies at bay.

Objective: Study the [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]{LOC_CIVIC_DISCIPLINE_NAME} [/b]Civic, the first step towards establishing a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} [/b][icon:NOTIFICATION_DECLARE_WAR] Military Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n][n]Remember: [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]Legacies [/b]improve your performance in later Ages, but [b]you can choose to pursue one, multiple, or none at all[/b].

Our army is now a well-honed sword and like a sword, it needs a strong hand to wield it. A {1_Icon} [b]{2_CommanderName}[/b] rises from the ranks, a charismatic soldier eager to lead our forces in battle.

A {1_Icon} [b]{2_CommanderName} [/b]is critical to managing any standing Military, and you'll continue to learn to use it over the course of many battles. Since it [b]cannot attack on its own[/b], you'll need to train an Army for it to lead. [n]Next Objective: [b]Train and assemble 4 Military Units [/b]and move them near your {1_Icon} [b]{2_CommanderName}[/b]. When adjacent, use the {1_Icon} [b]{2_CommanderName} [/b]to [b]pack [/b]them into an army using the [b]{LOC_UNITCOMMAND_PACK_ARMY_NAME} action[/b].
In order to protect our lands, we must make an example of our foes. But settlements are well-guarded these days. A siege weapon will make short work of their defenses.
Next Objective: Assemble an Army including at least one [b]Siege [/b]Unit. [n]Then, Attack and Capture another Civilization's Settlement.
A successful conquest! The world now knows of our might; so too do our people. But this is only the beginning. Let us continue our expansion, through war or settlement.

Next Objective: Earn [b]{1_NumVictoryPoints} [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} Legacy Points [/b]by conquering enemy Settlements and founding friendly Settlements Next Objective: Earn [b]{1_NumVictoryPoints} Legacy Points, the first Milestone to establish a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} [/b][icon:NOTIFICATION_DECLARE_WAR] Military Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n]Founded Settlements grant 1 Point. [n]Captured Settlements grant 2 Points.
Our empire grows, and with it our responsibility to keep the {1_CivAdj} citizens safe and prosperous. The world is full of dangers. The more of it we control, the fewer threats our people face.

Next Objective: Earn [b]{2_NumVictoryPoints} Legacy Points[/b], the second Milestone to establish a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} [/b][icon:NOTIFICATION_DECLARE_WAR] Military Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n]Founded Settlements grant 1 Point. [n]Captured Settlements grant 2 Points.
{1_CivAdj} settlements spread across the map, bolstered by the might of our armies and the vision of the people. Yet more lands await our guiding hand. Let us seize them now.

Next Objective: Earn [b]{1_NumVictoryPoints} Legacy Points[/b], the third and final step towards establishing a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} [/b][icon:NOTIFICATION_DECLARE_WAR] Military Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n]Founded Settlements grant 1 Point. [n]Captured Settlements grant 2 Points.
The world kneels before the vast {1_CivAdj} empire. Our settlements inscribe our presence upon the very earth, to be remembered forever.

Congratulations! You have earned 12 {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} Legacy Points, and finished the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_MILITARY_NAME} [/b][icon:NOTIFICATION_DECLARE_WAR] Military Legacy Path of the Antiquity Age.[n]You can visit the [b]Legacy Path Screen [/b]to see more Legacy Paths you can follow, or you can forge your own path.

You can now build the [b]{1_ImprovementName}[/b], a [b]{2_CivName} Unique Improvement[/b]![n][b]Unique Improvements [/b]are placed atop of existing Improvements (Rural tiles), and typically synergize well with your Civilization's specialties.

It looks like a [b]{1_ImprovementName} [/b]has been damaged by a disaster or raid. Some of the yields of {2_CityName} will be affected until it's fixed, so repairing it now can help you recover quickly.

A [b]{1_WarehouseName} [/b]has been built in [b]{2_CityName}[/b]! [n]The {1_WarehouseName} is a special type of Building called a [b]Warehouse[/b], which grows more efficient when its correlating [b]Improvements [/b](such as [b]Farms [/b]or [b]Mines[/b]) are present in the Settlement.

Enough time has passed since your War with {1_LeaderName} has begun, and you may want to stop the conflict. You now have the opportunity to make a [b]Peace Deal [/b]with them, and if they accept, end the War. [n]You can do this on any turn in the future via their [b]Diplomacy Screen[/b].

You now have enough [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]to Befriend [b]{1_PeopleName}[/b] and become its [b]Suzerain[/b]. [n]This title may take some time to earn, but it will grant you special bonuses from the experts in the Village, [b]visibility [/b]of its Units, the ability to [b]leverage [/b]them, and more.[n][b]Other Leaders can also Befriend this Village, [/b]but you can spend more [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [b]Influence [/b]to become Suzerain before they can.

When you direct your people to live on a rural tile, they create a structure to work the land called an [b]Improvement[/b]. Some [b]Policies[/b], [b]Unique Abilities[/b], and even [b]Buildings [/b]can further improve [b]Improvement [/b]yields.

You've [b]queued [/b]a second item in this City. [n]Cities can only make one thing at a time, so selecting another item to produce will add it to the queue. It will automatically start production once the first item is finished, but you can always rearrange or cancel items in the queue depending on your plans.

This is the Purchase Screen for {1_cityName}.[n]As you earn [icon:YIELD_GOLD] [b]Gold[/b], you will be able to purchase Units or Buildings for the Settlement.[n]Note: [b]Towns [/b]can only purchase some Buildings.

Remember: as {1_cityName} is a [b]Town[/b], it will not be able to [b]Produce [/b]anything; instead, its [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] [b]Production [/b]is converted into [icon:YIELD_GOLD] [b]Gold[/b].[n]You'll have to [b]convert [/b]{1_cityName} to a [b]City [/b]in order to produce items here.

Congratulations! Through thoughtful Diplomacy with this Village, you've become the [b]Suzerain [/b]of a new City-State![n]Suzerainty grants you [b]visibility [/b]of its Units, powerful ways to [b]levy [/b]its Resources, and a bonus determined by its specialty. [n][b]Choose your bonus now.[/b]
Eureka! Your people have produced a [b]Codex [/b]containing great wisdom. [n]Open the [b]Great Works screen [/b]to put the Codex on display.
Great Works, including the [b]Codex [/b]you earned, are managed here in the Great Works Screen. You will need to [b]slot [/b]these Great Works in your Cities to benefit from their effects.
The [b]Showcase [/b]on the left lists [b]all [/b]your Great Works.
The [b]Archive [/b]in the center shows all Great Works that are not [b]slotted [/b]into a Settlement and are therefore [b]inactive[/b].

On the right you can see all Settlements and their available slots. Your first [b]Codex [/b]has automatically been slotted in your Capital, but you will need to revisit this screen to [b]move it or slot more Codices[/b].[n]You can increase the number of slots a Settlement has by constructing specific [b]Buildings [/b]or [b]Wonders[/b].
The {1_CivAdj} Civilization continues to flourish! Now's a good time to remember what makes your [b]Leader [/b]and [b]Civilization [/b]different. [n]{2_ControlPrompt} your [b]Leader Portrait[/b].
Press [action:{1_Icon}] to access the [b]Radial Menu [/b]and select
This is your [b]Leader Screen[/b], where you can review choices you've made about your Leader and Civ.

There are four panels: [b]Diplomatic Actions[/b], [b]Independent Powers [/b]you've encountered, your [b]Government[/b], and your [b]Unique Abilities [/b]determined by your Leader and Civ.[n]You can return to this menu at any time by selecting your [b]Leader Portrait[/b].

The [icon:NOTIFICATION_DISCOVER_RESOURCE] [b]Resource Screen [/b]is where you view and manage the Resources you've acquired via [b]Improvements [/b]and [icon:NOTIFICATION_TRADE_ROUTE_TO_YOU] [b]Trade Routes[/b]. [n]At the top are your [b]Empire Resources[/b], which affect your entire Civilization. [n]On the left are your unassigned [b]City [/b]and [b]Bonus [/b]Resources. [n]On the right are your [b]Settlements [/b]and the Resources assigned to them. [n]To assign a Resource, select one from the left, then select an empty slot in the desired Settlement. [b]City Resources [/b]can only be assigned to Cities, but [b]Bonus Resources [/b]can be assigned to either Towns or Cities.

You can now build an [icon:BUILDING_ALTAR] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_ALTAR_NAME}[/b]! Depending on the [b]Pantheon [/b]you chose, you may need an [icon:BUILDING_ALTAR] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_ALTAR_NAME} [/b]to receive its effects. [n]An {LOC_BUILDING_ALTAR_NAME} also contributes a base amount of [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] [b]Happiness [/b]to your Settlement.

Your {1_UnitName} has just set foot in enemy territory. To take [b]{2_CityName}[/b], you will need to [b]destroy its defenses [/b]and [b]occupy [/b]all [b]Fortified Districts [/b]and the [b]Settlement Center[/b].
Your War with {1_otherLeader} has ended. Since you've Declared Peace, [b]you and {1_otherLeader} are unable to Declare War on each other for the next 10 turns[/b].

{1_unitText}Independent Powers and City-States are unique to a given Age, making way for new ones to rise in the following Age. If you want to maintain control over the territory of a City-State, be sure to [b]incorporate [/b]it into your empire before the Age ends!

Some, if not all, of your Units will survive through Age Transition. At the start of the Exploration Age, {1_UnitCount} Units will remain to defend your Settlements, and the rest will be assigned to Commanders, as long as there is space for them. [b]Any other Units you have will be left behind[/b]![n]
